Expectation1: Provide guidance and wisdom based on life experience
Situation1: The grandfather notices his grandchild seems to be feeling lost or discouraged about a personal matter.
Situation2: A life-support device in the intensive care unit is flashing critical fault codes.
Story: I was sitting in the living room, watching my grandson fidget with his hands, his eyes downcast. He’d barely touched his snack, and I could sense the weight on his young shoulders. As his grandfather, I wanted nothing more than to offer him the right words, to share some hard-earned wisdom that might help him find his way. Just as I leaned forward to speak, my phone buzzed urgently. The hospital’s number flashed on the screen. I was needed immediately—one of the life-support machines in the ICU was failing, and every second counted. My mind raced. My family expected me to be present, to guide and comfort. But as a machine repairer, I was the only one who could fix that device, and lives depended on my expertise. I looked at my grandson, then at the phone in my hand, feeling the pressure of both worlds closing in. My heart ached as I realized I couldn’t be in two places at once.
